report_title: Musical Instrument and Supplies Stores Industry Report
executive_summary: The Musical Instrument and Supplies Stores industry has fallen out of tune as strong external competition has drowned out the sound made by independent stores. As large-scale retailers and online stores made their way into the musical equipment industry, accelerated by COVID-19, traditional brick-and-mortar retailers experienced revenue steadily fall over the past five years. Music stores that have expanded into the online space have experienced more success than those operating strictly in physical locations, but they still have struggled to compete with the prices of larger retailers. Industry revenue is expected to fall at a CAGR of 1.0% to $6.0 billion in 2024, despite a dip of just 1.0% in 2024 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Heightened external competition has created difficulties for business owners
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Mass merchandisers have increasingly added musical instruments and accessories to their product offerings and can negotiate lower prices with manufacturers due to their large size. Music stores have been forced to offer products that differentiate themselves from large retailers, such as unique instrument accessories, high-quality products and hard-to-find instruments that would not be available at less specialized stores. Furthermore, music stores are also able to offer key services such as instrument tuning and music classes that are not available at big-box retailers. However, profit has remained more stable as music stores have moved into these higher value roles for musicians.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Online Shopping Presents Opportunities and Challenges for Music Stores
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The rise of online shopping has had a dual impact on music stores. On one hand, e-commerce has allowed businesses to reach a wider audience than traditional brick-and-mortar stores, boosting sales, and facilitating international expansion. Conversely, it has also increased competition, as products from around the world are now readily available. Many traditional stores have grappled with adapting to digital platforms and competing with established online marketplaces.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: TOUGH COMPETITION EMERGES FROM BIG-BOX DISCOUNT STORES
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The wide availability of low-cost, imported instruments and accessories has benefited music stores by lowering purchase costs. However, competition has increased from discount retailers, such as Walmart and Best Buy which have more substantial negotiating power than this industry's typically tiny, single-owner operators. Local stores also cannot purchase sheet music or other mass-manufactured music items in the same volume as larger chain retailers. To enhance competition, music stores have shifted to a focus on quality, offering excellent customer service, instrument trials and even music community events.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: SHORT-TERM HOBBIES DROWN OUT THE CHALLENGES OF MUSIC EDUCATION
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Advances in technology have driven mass adoption of advanced gaming consoles and smartphones, which serve as attractive alternatives to learning and playing a musical instrument for younger consumers. Since hobbyists account for a large share of demand, these alternative leisure activities have effectively reduced the number of consumers that decide to pursue musical instruments, leading to lower demand for musical goods across the board. Fortunately for music stores, online tablature, digital tuning devices, mobile tuning apps and free online lessons and tutorials have made instruments less tricky for beginners to learn.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: GROWING MUSIC INTEREST WILL BENEFIT MUSIC STORES
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Expanding consumer interest in music will be a key driver for music stores over the next five years. The rise in popularity of various music genres and artists, driven by globalization and digital media, will inspire more people to engage with music actively. As people explore different facets of the music world, demand for a diverse range of instruments and equipment will increase, pushing growth for musical instrument and supplies stores.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: COMPETITION FROM EXTERNAL PHYSICAL RETAILERS RISES
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Though interest in musical instruments will keep increasing over the next several years, increased competition from big-box retailers, like Walmart and Best Buy, will hinder revenue for musical instrument and supplies stores. Large-scale retailers can use economies of scale to their advantage and get more products to sell at less high prices than small music stores. These stores have the infrastructure and supply chain relationships to quickly and inexpensively expand their music segments and carry a wide variety of instruments, digital equipment and accessories.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: CHANGING HABITS AND NEEDS PUSH CONSUMERS TO ELECTRONIC MUSIC
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: According to music streaming service Spotify data, Hip-Hop/Rap and Electronic Dance Music (EDM) are two of the top four most popular music genres in the United States. Similar to how guitar stores began opening all over the West Coast during the mid-20th century as Rock n Roll became a staple, electronic music synthesizing equipment will become a major industry sector because of its role in music production for the current popular genres.

industry_definition: The Musical Instrument and Supplies Stores industry retails an extensive selection of musical instruments, sheet music and related supplies, such as microphones, amplifiers and audio systems. These products are usually sold directly to end consumers. Many industry operators also repair and rent these products and provide music instruction.
key_trends: Music stores experience greater competition from external marketplaces than from other music retailers. Stores that are unable to compete on price or product offering often end up closing.
Quality of service is the most important differentiator for many music stores. Price, while important for education markets, is less.
Music stores are being aggressively replaced by big-box retailers and online merchants.
The distribution of establishments for the Musical Instrument and Supplies Stores industry closely follows the United States population.
Purchases are the largest cost for musical instrument and supplies stores, and the prices at these stores are higher.
Many music stores are considered nonemployers.
Profit has continued to stagnate as external competition has increased.
Large cities with famous music groups tend to contain more music stores for residents.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Hobbyists form a large segment of the Musical Instrument and Supplies Stores industry; many individuals, including children, adults and retirees, play musical instruments in their leisure time as a way to relax or learn new skills.
Professional and semiprofessional musicians are estimated to account for a large share of revenue for musical instrument and supplies stores revenue.
Aspiring student musicians and their tutors are a substantial market for this industry, generating almost half of the industry revenue.

products_and_services.product_description: A variety of other new instruments available.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Used Violins, Drums, Guitars and Other Instruments
products_and_services.product_description: Affordable used instruments for budget-conscious buyers.
Newly crafted pianos offered for sale.
Electronic equipment refers to radios, stereos, tape recorders and players, CD players and other sound reinforcement and recording equipment.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Services such as Lessons and Repairs
products_and_services.product_description: Many store owners offer services that include instrument rentals, music lessons and equipment repair.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Consumer spending is an important statistic to examine because it captures the overall state of how consumers are affecting the economy.
Musical instruments and supplies are generally discretionary purchases; therefore, a rise in household disposable income increases the propensity for consumers to purchase industry goods.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Time Spent on Leisure and Sports
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Fluctuations in the availability of consumer leisure time directly affect demand for musical instruments.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region of the US has the highest percentage of music stores at 37%, while its population percentage is 22%.
The large number of music stores in the West region of the US can be attributed to several factors.
The Mid-Atlantic region's large number of music stores is greatly influenced by its demographic and economic factors.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The life cycle stage of the industry is in decline.
There is no industry assistance, which is steady.
The capital intensity level is low, decreasing barriers.
The concentration level is low, decreasing barriers.
There is no regulation, which is steady.
The globalization level is low and steady.

factors_increased_barrier: The life cycle stage is in decline.
factors_decreased_barrier: The capital intensity level is low.
There is no regulation, which is steady.
The globalization level is low and steady.

basis_points.basis_description: Music stores experience greater competition from external marketplaces than from other music retailers.
Quality of service is the most important differentiator for many music stores.

basis_points.basis_title: Price less critical for music education
basis_points.basis_description: Price, while important for education markets, is less critical considering the value of a music education.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Aside from its largest player, this industry is highly fragmented because of the large number of independent operators running traditional family owned retail outlets in local or regional areas.
Many of the industry's businesses are defined as nonemployers, which consist of businesses that either have no paid employees, are self-employing or operate as a partnership.
Most stores in the industry specialize within one product area (percussion, string, wind or brass) due to the breadth and depth of each segment, creating further fragmentation.
Another barrier to concentration is the popularity of physical stores with musicians.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases remain the largest cost for retailers
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase costs have remained relatively stable over the past five years, only increasingly slightly.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Profit continues to lag as music stores struggle
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit varies between musical instrument and supplies stores depending on the retailers size, product selection and location.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Stocking Unique Instruments and Assisting Customers is Wage Intensive
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages are a significant expense for the hard-to-automate music industry sales sector.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Music stores rely on employees to drive sales, host lessons and manage stock levels.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Market Trends And Seasonal Demand Affect Volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: New product launches and technological advances dictate market trends for musical instruments and supplies stores.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Seasonal demand also contributes to price fluctuations
volatility_points.volatility_description: Peak buying times, like holiday seasons, boosts demand and increase prices.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Economic and Global Factors Impact Volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Economic conditions greatly impact the Musical Instruments and Supplies Stores industry.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The integration of cutting-edge technologies is leading to innovations in the product lineup of musical instruments and supplies stores.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Service Innovations Are Being Sparked By Digitization
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The rise of e-commerce platforms has revolutionized the way products are bought and delivered.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Company sales are typically correlated with the health of the economy.

FAQs.question: How has your business adapted to the growth of online sales in recent years?
FAQs.answer: Online sales hurt industry growth as consumers shift to purchasing musical lessons and products online.
